title: How to Decorate Easter Eggs with Confetti

steps.headline: Prepare your eggs.
steps.description: You can use hard boiled or blown-out eggs for this method. If you plan on using blown-out eggs, cover the holes with some paper clay or speckling. White eggs will give you the best contrast, but you can use brown eggs for something different too.

steps.headline: Pour the confetti onto a plate or into a shallow bowl.
steps.description: You can use store-bought confetti or make your own using colorful tissue paper. For a more interesting effect, cut up some gold foil and 4 to 6 colors of tissue paper, and use that instead. Use round, tissue paper confetti for a polka dot effect. Make your own confetti by cutting tissue paper into tiny squares or triangles.

steps.headline: Paint the egg with a generous coat of Mod Podge.
steps.description: You can use a paintbrush or a foam brush. Keep your fingers clean by holding the egg between your thumb and pointer finger. If you can't find any Mod Podge, you can use another type of decoupage glue. You can also make your own by mixing equal parts of white school glue and water.

steps.headline: Roll the egg across the confetti.
steps.description: Spread the confetti out a little first. This way, you won't get clumps of confetti sticking to your egg. Set the egg down into the confetti and roll it back and forth. Don't forget to coat the top and bottom! The confetti will stick to the Mod Podge. Try to leave some white gaps on your egg. Alternatively, you can pick up bits of confetti and sprinkle them onto your egg instead.

steps.headline: Let the egg dry.
steps.description: Set the egg down onto a sheet of wax paper or parchment paper and let it dry completely. If you want to, you can try setting it into an egg holder, but be aware that the egg may stick to it due to the Mod Podge.

steps.headline: Paint the egg with another coat of Mod Podge.
steps.description: Set the egg down into an egg holder and paint it with a coat of Mod Podge. Be sure to smooth down the confetti pieces as you go. Let the egg dry, then flip it over and paint the other side. This will help keep your fingers clean. If you used only shiny confetti, you may want to skip this step.

steps.headline: Let the egg dry completely.
steps.description: Once the egg is dry, you can display it or place it into your basket.

steps.headline: Prepare your egg.
steps.description: This method works best with hallow or blown-out eggs. You can also try using hard boiled eggs, but you won't be able to eat them if the paint soaks through the shell. Since you will be painting the egg, the color does not matter.

steps.headline: Paint the egg a solid color using acrylic paint.
steps.description: To keep your fingers clean, paint half of the egg first. Let it dry, then flip it over and paint the other side. Pastel colors work best, since they will create the most contrast.

steps.headline: Paint half of the egg using Mod Podge.
steps.description: You can also use a different type of decoupage glue. If you can't find either, make your own by mixing equal parts of white school glue and water. Skip the top coat. You can paint the top or bottom half of the egg. It's up to you! How far up you paint the egg with Mod Podge is up to you.

steps.headline: Dip the egg into metallic confetti.
steps.description: Fill a bowl with shiny, metallic confetti. Holding the egg by the unpainted side, dip it into the confetti. Roll it around so that the confetti sticks to the Mod Podge. For an ombre effect, set the egg into an egg holder, Mod Podge side up, then sprinkle the confetti on top. Don't worry if the confetti sticks out. This will give the egg some interesting texture!

steps.headline: Set the egg into an egg holder.
steps.description: Once the egg is covered to your liking, take it out of the bowl, and set it down into an egg holder. Make sure that the confetti side is sticking up.

steps.headline: Let the egg dry.
steps.description: Some of the confetti may come loose after the egg dries, which is normal. Simply dust it off using a soft brush or blow on it.

steps.headline: Display the egg.
steps.description: Once the egg is dry, it's ready to be tucked into your Easter basket or set on the mantle for display. Do not coat the egg with more Mod Podge, or you will dull down the confetti's shine.
